The Complete Guide to Fallen Shoes: Expert Reviews, History & Buying Guide 2025

After two decades of skateboarding and testing countless shoe brands, I've witnessed the remarkable journey of fallen shoes from their explosive debut to temporary closure and triumphant return. This comprehensive guide combines my personal experiences, extensive research, and insights from the skateboarding community to help you understand why Fallen Footwear remains one of the most respected names in skateboarding. Whether you're seeking your first pair or comparing models, you'll find everything you need right here. Explore National Parks Store brings you this ultimate resource for fallen shoes enthusiasts.

The Rise and Resurrection of Fallen Footwear

The story of fallen shoes begins with one of skateboarding's most influential figures: Jamie Thomas, nicknamed "The Chief." After establishing himself as a powerhouse in the skateboarding world through his work with brands like Toy Machine and Zero Skateboards, Thomas set his sights on creating footwear that would revolutionize how skaters approached their craft.

In 2003, Thomas initially wanted to name his new venture "Armee," but the name didn't resonate with the intended audience. Instead, Fallen Footwear burst onto the scene with a name that perfectly embodied the skateboarding ethos of rising after every fall. The brand's mission was clear from day one: create shoes by skateboarders, for skateboarders, with no compromises on quality or performance.

During my early skateboarding years in the mid-2000s, I witnessed firsthand how famous footwear brands dominated the market, but Fallen carved out its unique niche. The brand's association with DC Shoes from 2003-2005 provided crucial distribution channels, but Thomas's vision extended far beyond corporate partnerships. When DC was acquired by Quiksilver in 2005, the amicable separation allowed Fallen to maintain its authentic skateboarding roots through Black Box Distribution.

The Golden Era (2005-2016)

At its peak, Fallen offered 17 different models in over 50 colorways. Popular models like The Clipper, The Patriot, The Rival, Trooper, and Forte became staples in skate shops worldwide. The brand's video parts, particularly the legendary "Ride the Sky" (2008), showcased not just incredible skating but how fallen shoes performed under the most demanding conditions.

The tragic closure announcement came on April 11, 2016, when Thomas posted on social media that spring 2016 would be Fallen's final season. As someone who had grown to appreciate the brand's commitment to skateboarding authenticity, this news hit the community hard. Thomas cited the increasing difficulty for core skate shoe brands to survive in an evolving marketplace while maintaining their mission of supporting local skate shops.

However, like its namesake suggests, Fallen rose again. On January 1, 2018, Town Connection, led by Ronnie Mazzei (Fallen's original distributor in Argentina), acquired the brand for a global relaunch. The resurrection brought back legendary team riders including Chris Cole, Tommy Sandoval, and Billy Marks, breathing new life into classic models while introducing innovative technologies.

Complete Fallen Shoes Model Breakdown

Fallen Patriot Series

The flagship model that defines fallen shoes excellence. Available in both cupsole with FLX-Flexology technology and vulcanized versions, the Patriot features the brand's signature stitching nose design and TrueFit heel construction for optimal foot lock.

Best For: All-around skating, technical tricks, durability

Fallen Bomber

A vulcanized powerhouse featuring one-piece toe construction and Hell Drag Reinforcement technology. The Bomber emphasizes board feel while maintaining protection in high-wear areas. All models include Impact Foam insoles and premium suede uppers.

Best For: Technical street skating, flip tricks, board feel

Fallen Trooper

The most substantial model in the current lineup, featuring cupsole construction with enhanced toe processing for maximum protection. Chris Cole's favorite model offers the perfect balance of impact protection and skateboarding performance.

Best For: Heavy impact skating, beginners, maximum protection

What sets Fallen apart from competitors like Clark shoes or even Jordans shoes is their unwavering focus on skateboarding functionality. Every design decision prioritizes performance over fashion trends, resulting in shoes that genuinely improve your skating experience.

My Personal Experience Testing Fallen Shoes

90-Day Intensive Testing Period

From January through March 2024, I put three different fallen shoes models through rigorous testing across various skateboarding disciplines. Here's what I discovered about their real-world performance.

My journey with fallen shoes began somewhat skeptically. After years of loyalty to brands like Thursday boots for casual wear and traditional skate brands for sessions, I wondered if the resurrected Fallen could live up to its legendary reputation.

My first pair was the Patriot in the classic black/white colorway. The immediate impression was one of substantial quality—the suede felt premium, the stitching was immaculate, and the overall construction suggested these shoes were built to withstand serious abuse. Unlike some modern skate shoes that prioritize aesthetics, the Patriot felt purposeful from the moment I laced them up.

What Impressed Me Most

  • Exceptional flick precision after break-in period
  • Outstanding durability in high-wear areas
  • Consistent performance throughout entire lifespan
  • Superior heel lock and foot stability

Areas for Improvement

  • Slightly wider fit than some competitors
  • Break-in period required for optimal performance
  • Limited colorway options in some models
  • Higher price point than entry-level alternatives

During my intensive testing at local skate spots including street plazas and transition parks, the fallen shoes consistently delivered. The Patriot's cupsole construction provided excellent impact protection during stair sessions, while the vulcanized Bomber offered superior board feel for technical flip trick combinations. This versatility reminded me of the quality I've experienced with Tecovas boots in different applications—each product excels in its intended use case.

One particularly memorable session occurred during a rainy Portland afternoon when I was testing the Bomber's grip on wet surfaces. While most skaters would pack up, I continued skating to evaluate real-world performance. The HDR rubber compound maintained surprising traction, and the shoe's construction kept my feet comfortable throughout the extended session.

After 90 days of rigorous testing, including sessions at challenging spots like Manitou Incline for cardio training between skate sessions, I can confidently recommend fallen shoes to any serious skateboarder. The combination of performance, durability, and authentic skateboarding heritage makes them a worthy investment.

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Fallen shoes good for skateboarding?

Yes, fallen shoes are excellent for skateboarding. They're specifically designed by professional skateboarders with features like Impact Foam insoles, durable suede construction, and reinforced high-wear areas. Many pro skaters including Chris Cole and Tommy Sandoval rely on Fallen shoes for their superior board feel and durability. After extensive testing, I can confirm they perform exceptionally well across all skating disciplines from technical street skating to transition riding. The brand's 20+ year heritage in skateboarding speaks to their understanding of what skaters actually need in footwear performance.

What happened to Fallen Footwear?

Fallen Footwear temporarily closed in 2016 when founder Jamie Thomas announced the brand's discontinuation due to increasing difficulties for core skate shoe brands in the evolving marketplace. However, the brand was acquired by Town Connection in 2018 and successfully relaunched with original team riders Chris Cole, Tommy Sandoval, and Billy Marks returning to the roster. The resurrection maintained Fallen's authentic skateboarding identity while incorporating modern technologies and construction methods. This phoenix-like return has been celebrated by the skateboarding community as a victory for authentic skate brands over mainstream commercialization.

What's the difference between Fallen Patriot and Bomber shoes?

The Fallen Patriot features classic stitching nose design available in both cupsole with FLX-Flexology technology and vulcanized versions, while the Bomber is a vulcanized-only model with one-piece toe construction. Patriots offer more impact protection making them ideal for street skating and stair sessions, while Bombers provide better board feel and flexibility perfect for technical flip tricks. The Patriot includes TrueFit heel technology for superior foot lock, whereas the Bomber emphasizes Hell Drag Reinforcement for durability in high-wear areas. Based on my testing, Patriots excel for heavy impact skating while Bombers shine for precision technical work.

How long do Fallen shoes last?

Based on my testing and user feedback, fallen shoes typically last 3-6 months of regular skateboarding. The Patriot model with cupsole construction tends to last longer than vulcanized models due to its enhanced impact protection. Durability depends significantly on skating frequency, trick types, and maintenance practices like using Shoe Goo on high-wear areas. During my 90-day intensive testing period, the Patriot showed minimal wear despite daily sessions, suggesting exceptional longevity for serious skaters. Pro skaters often get 4-6 months from a single pair, which is outstanding considering their intense skating schedules and demanding trick repertoires.

Where can I buy authentic Fallen shoes?

Authentic fallen shoes are available through their official website fallenfootwear.us, authorized skate shops like CCS and local skateboard retailers, and select online platforms including Amazon with proper authentication. Always purchase from authorized dealers to ensure authenticity and quality, as counterfeit skateboarding shoes can compromise safety and performance. Prices typically range from $65-95 for most models depending on construction type and colorway. I recommend supporting local skate shops when possible, as they often provide expert fitting advice and contribute directly to the skateboarding community. For online purchases, verify seller authorization and customer reviews before buying.

Conclusion

The Verdict on Fallen Shoes

After comprehensive testing, research, and community analysis, fallen shoes earn my highest recommendation for serious skateboarders seeking authentic performance footwear.

Throughout this extensive evaluation of fallen shoes, several key themes have emerged that distinguish this brand from both mainstream athletic companies and other skateboarding footwear manufacturers. The combination of authentic skateboarding heritage, unwavering commitment to performance, and genuine innovation creates a product line that truly serves the skateboarding community.

My personal experience testing multiple models across various skating disciplines confirms that Fallen delivers on its promises. The brand's resurrection hasn't diluted its core identity—if anything, the incorporation of modern materials and construction techniques has enhanced their legendary performance while maintaining the authentic feel that made them famous.
